Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Determine delta re WhiteSource vs GitHub vulnerabilities, ascertain priority of including WhiteSource" (#8379) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: We don't see https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2020-1469 in GitHub. How many others are there, and how many apply to NuGet.org packages?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Getting messages as package id is reserved contact the owner when uploading new packages" (#8378) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,
 I am trying to upload a new package which starts with IBM.Data.Db2.NET5 but keep getting messages something like 
" This package ID has been reserved. Please request access to upload to this reserved namespace from the owner of the reserved prefix, or re-upload the package with a different ID."
We are the owners of these namespace (IBM.Data.DB2  series) and its not sure who could reserve these names and how to get them back. 
The other variants of the above name also did not succeed.

Thanks and regards
Vishwa

Opened issue "Dont hide exception stacktrace in packtask" (#10464) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

When a top level exception occurs in packtask, the stack trace is hiddin. this makes it difficult to work out what the underlying issue is.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/122666/104988693-dc10fa00-5a6c-11eb-81b4-d7069a7f58f4.png)


## Product version: 

see environment below

## Repro steps and/or sample project

difficult to create a repro when cant work out what the issue it


Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Embed the pdbs in the release packages" (#7552) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: As far as I can tell SourceLink doesn't work because the pdb-s are not in the package. That just makes debugging NuGet itself difficult.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Error NETSDK1005 “Assets file 'C: \Users\v-minlon\source\repos\RRR02\RRR02\obj\project.assets.json' doesn't have a target for 'net5.0'.” occurs when building solution after enabling “RestoreLockedMode”" (#10462) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
VS Version: Main\30917.09
NuGet Version : Dev\5.9.0.7050
OS Version: Windows-10-Enterprise-19H2.
## Installation
1. Install VS Main\30917.09: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=4380664&view=ms.vss-build-web.run-extensions-tab
2. Install NuGet Dev\5.9.0.7050: \\\ddfiles\drops\NuGet\Drops\CI\NuGet.Client\Dev\5.9.0.7050\artifacts\VS15\NuGet.Tools.vsix
## Repro steps 
1. Create a C# Console Application (.Net Core) project.
2. Install a few ‘PackageReference’ packages into the projects.
3. Set MSBuild property “RestorePackagesWithLockFile” to true in csproj file.
  `<RestorePackagesWithLockFile>true</RestorePackagesWithLockFile>`
4. Do a restore.
5. Check it should have generated ‘packages.lock.json’ file alongside *.csproj file.
6. Set msbuild property “RestoreLockedMode” to “true”.
    `<RestoreLockedMode>true</RestoreLockedMode>`
7. Install another package.
8. It should still work fine and update ‘packages.lock.json’ file.
9. Manually add a new PackageReference item into csproj file.
  `<PackageReference Include="NUnit" Version="3.12.0" />` 
 10. Perform restore.
 11. Build the solution.
 1. Create a C# Console Application (.Net Core) project.
2. Install a few ‘PackageReference’ packages into the projects.
3. Set MSBuild property “RestorePackagesWithLockFile” to true in csproj file.
  <RestorePackagesWithLockFile>true</RestorePackagesWithLockFile>
4. Do a restore.
5. Check it should have generated ‘packages.lock.json’ file alongside *.csproj file.
6. Set msbuild property “RestoreLockedMode” to “true”.
    <RestoreLockedMode>true</RestoreLockedMode>
7. Install another package.
8. It should still work fine and update ‘packages.lock.json’ file.
9. Manually add a new PackageReference item into csproj file.
  <PackageReference Include="NUnit" Version="3.12.0" /> 
 10. Perform restore.
 11. Build the solution
1. Create a C# Console Application (.Net Core) project.
2. Install a few ‘PackageReference’ packages into the projects.
3. Set MSBuild property “RestorePackagesWithLockFile” to true in csproj file.
  <RestorePackagesWithLockFile>true</RestorePackagesWithLockFile>
4. Do a restore.
5. Check it should have generated ‘packages.lock.json’ file alongside *.csproj file.
6. Set msbuild property “RestoreLockedMode” to “true”.
    <RestoreLockedMode>true</RestoreLockedMode>
7. Install another package.
8. It should still work fine and update ‘packages.lock.json’ file.
9. Manually add a new PackageReference item into csproj file.
  <PackageReference Include="NUnit" Version="3.12.0" /> 
 10. Perform restore.
 11. Build the solution
## Expected 
Only expected error NU1004 shows on error list when building the solution.
## Actual
Error NETSDK1005 “Assets file 'C:\Users\v-minlon\source\repos\RRR02\RRR02\obj\project.assets.json' doesn't have a target for 'net5.0'” occurs when building the solution as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/104896436-123d7380-59b2-11eb-9dbc-e11b6f5216a0.png)
## Notes
1. The issue also reproes on C# Class Library (.Net Framework) project, the error message as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/104896536-34cf8c80-59b2-11eb-9d4b-32cb18982c8d.png)
2. The issue starts from Dev\5.9.0.7043.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PackageReference NU1604 error handling is different across VS and command line (Restore & Package Manager UI)" (#9289) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Specifically if a PackageReference version is a property and that property is not set. 
* On the commandline the customer will get NU1604 and a restore.
* In VS, the whole operation fails. 

Worth clarifying in both SDK and non-SDK cases. 

See internal thread `RE: NuGet Package Manager does not work in VS`

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Signing: Design dotnet package signing commands" (#9010) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Write up an RFC describing the commands and options and get it reviewed before implementing the actual commands.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "When restoring at normal verbosity, log which source a package is being restored from" (#10461) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently, when restoring at normal verbosity, I get an error message when a package is being installed, but it doesn't say from where. It might be implied if it's downloaded from an HTTP source, but if it's found on a local source, there's nothing in the log to explain where it came from.

Currently:

```text
Restoring packages for C:\src\NuGet.Client\build\bootstrap.proj...
Installing Newtonsoft.Json 9.0.1
Committing restore...
Writing assets file to disk. Path: C:\src\NuGet.Client\packages\obj\project.assets.json
Restored C:\src\NuGet.Client\build\bootstrap.proj (in 679 ms).
```

Desired: the "installing" line should read:

```text
Installing Newtonsoft.Json 9.0.1 from C:\src\nupkgs\.
```


Note, https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/3700 https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/3055 added the source to diagnostic verbosity, but this request is for "normal" verbosity.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	· UTC-1 to UTC+6 – [Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	· UTC+7 to UTC-10 – [Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.

Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
 
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	· **Nov. 11, 2020** – 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	· **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**  – 48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
 
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	· UTC-9 to UTC-2 – [Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
